hints.label: def-path-space-metric
hints.title: Path Space Riemannian Metric
hints.content:
1172: :label: def-path-space-metric
1173: 
1174: The **Riemannian metric** $g_{\mathcal{P}}$ on path space $\mathcal{P}$ at a path $\gamma$ is defined by the Hessian of the action:
1175: 
1176: $$
1177: g_{\mathcal{P}}[\gamma](h_1, h_2) := D^2 S[\gamma](h_1, h_2)
1178: $$
1179: 
1180: for $h_1, h_2 \in T_\gamma \mathcal{P} = H$ (Cameron-Martin space).
1181: 
1182: **Explicit Formula:**
1183: 
1184: $$
1185: g_{\mathcal{P}}[\gamma](h_1, h_2) = \int_0^T \langle h_1(t), \mathcal{G}(t) h_2(t) \rangle_{\mathcal{M}} dt
1186: $$
1187: 
1188: where $\mathcal{G}(t)$ is the Hessian operator:
1189: 
1190: $$
1191: \mathcal{G}(t) = \begin{pmatrix}
1192: \nabla_x^2 L(x_t, v_t, \dot{v}_t) & \nabla_x \nabla_v L \\
1193: \nabla_v \nabla_x L & \nabla_v^2 L
1194: \end{pmatrix}
1195: $$
1196: 
1197: **Non-degeneracy:**
hints.raw_directive:
1169: The second variation of the action defines a Riemannian metric on path space.

hints.label: prop-metric-from-om-action
hints.title: Metric from Onsager-Machlup Action (Respecting Kinematic Constraint)
hints.content:
1203: :label: prop-metric-from-om-action
1204: 
1205: For the Fragile Gas Onsager-Machlup action {prf:ref}`def-reduced-om-action`, the path space metric is the **second functional derivative** (Hessian) of the action, properly accounting for the kinematic constraint $\dot{x} = v$.
1206: 
1207: **Key Insight:**
1208: 
1209: Perturbations $h = (h_x, h_v)$ in the Cameron-Martin space must respect the linearized kinematic constraint:
1210: 
1211: $$
1212: \dot{h}_x(t) = h_v(t) \quad \text{for almost every } t \in [0,T]
1213: $$
1214: 
1215: This means the tangent space consists of pairs $(h_x, \dot{h}_x)$, and we can parameterize perturbations by $h_x$ alone.
1216: 
1217: **Derivation:**
1218: 
1219: The Lagrangian is:
1220: 
1221: $$
1222: L(x, v, \dot{v}) = \frac{1}{4\gamma T} \|\dot{v} + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) + \gamma v\|^2
1223: $$
1224: 
1225: Substitute the constraint $v = \dot{x}$ and $\dot{v} = \ddot{x}$ to obtain the **reduced action**:
1226: 
1227: $$
1228: S[x] = \frac{1}{4\gamma T}\int_0^T \|\ddot{x}_t + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) + \gamma \dot{x}_t\|^2 dt
1229: $$
1230: 
1231: This is now a functional of the position path $x(t)$ alone.
1232: 
1233: **Second Variation:**
1234: 
1235: For a perturbation $x \to x + \epsilon h_x$ with $h_x(0) = h_x(T) = 0$, expand to second order:
1236: 
1237: $$
1238: D^2 S[x](h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \|\ddot{h}_x + \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t) \dot{h}_x + \gamma \dot{h}_x + (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)) h_x\|^2 dt
1239: $$
1240: 
1241: Along an **extremal path** where $\ddot{x} + \nabla U_{\text{eff}}(x) + \gamma \dot{x} = 0$, simplify:
1242: 
1243: $$
1244: D^2 S[x](h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \|\ddot{h}_x + \gamma \dot{h}_x + (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)) h_x\|^2 dt
1245: $$
1246: 
1247: Expanding the norm:
1248: 
1249: $$
1250: g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \left[ \|\ddot{h}_x\|^2 + \gamma^2 \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 + h_x^T (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}})^2 h_x + 2\gamma \langle \ddot{h}_x, \dot{h}_x \rangle + \cdots \right] dt
1251: $$
1252: 
1253: After integration by parts (using $h_x(0) = h_x(T) = 0$ and $\dot{h}_x(0) = \dot{h}_x(T) = 0$):
1254: 
1255: $$
1256: g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \left[ \|\ddot{h}_x\|^2 + \gamma^2 \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 + h_x^T (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}})^2 h_x + 2\gamma\langle \ddot{h}_x, \dot{h}_x \rangle + 2\langle \ddot{h}_x, (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}) h_x \rangle + 2\gamma \langle \dot{h}_x, (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}) h_x \rangle \right] dt
1257: $$
1258: 
1259: **Simplified Form for Operator Analysis:**
1260: 
1261: Define the **linearized Langevin operator**:
1262: 
1263: $$
1264: \mathcal{L} h_x := \ddot{h}_x + \gamma \dot{h}_x + (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)) h_x
1265: $$
1266: 
1267: Then:
1268: 
1269: $$
1270: g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \|\mathcal{L} h_x\|^2 dt
1271: $$
1272:

hints.label: thm-riemannian-metric-convex
hints.title: Riemannian Metric Under Convexity
hints.content:
1279: :label: thm-riemannian-metric-convex
1280: 
1281: If the effective potential $U_{\text{eff}}$ is **strictly convex**, i.e.,
1282: 
1283: $$
1284: \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x) \succeq \epsilon I \quad \text{for some } \epsilon > 0 \text{ and all } x \in \mathcal{X}
1285: $$
1286: 
1287: then the path space metric $g_{\mathcal{P}}$ is **positive-definite**, and $(\mathcal{P}, g_{\mathcal{P}})$ is a **Riemannian manifold**.
1288: 
1289: **Proof:**
1290: 
1291: By {prf:ref}`prop-metric-from-om-action`, the metric in terms of the linearized Langevin operator $\mathcal{L} h_x = \ddot{h}_x + \gamma \dot{h}_x + (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}) h_x$ is:
1292: 
1293: $$
1294: g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \|\mathcal{L} h_x\|^2 dt
1295: $$
1296: 
1297: We must show that for any non-zero $h_x \in W^{2,2}_0([0,T], \mathbb{R}^d)$ (i.e., $h_x(0) = h_x(T) = 0$ and $\int |\ddot{h}_x|^2 dt < \infty$), we have $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) > 0$.
1298: 
1299: **Step 1: Assume g = 0 for contradiction.**
1300: 
1301: Suppose $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = 0$ for some $h_x \neq 0$. Then:
1302: 
1303: $$
1304: \mathcal{L} h_x(t) = \ddot{h}_x + \gamma \dot{h}_x + (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)) h_x = 0 \quad \text{a.e. on } [0,T]
1305: $$
1306: 
1307: **Step 2: Multiply by $h_x$ and integrate.**
1308: 
1309: $$
1310: \int_0^T \langle \mathcal{L} h_x, h_x \rangle dt = \int_0^T \left[\langle \ddot{h}_x, h_x \rangle + \gamma \langle \dot{h}_x, h_x \rangle + \langle (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}) h_x, h_x \rangle \right] dt = 0
1311: $$
1312: 
1313: **Step 3: Integration by parts.**
1314: 
1315: For the first term:
1316: 
1317: $$
1318: \int_0^T \langle \ddot{h}_x, h_x \rangle dt = \underbrace{[\langle \dot{h}_x, h_x \rangle]_0^T}_{=0} - \int_0^T \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt = -\int_0^T \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt
1319: $$
1320: 
1321: For the second term:
1322: 
1323: $$
1324: \gamma \int_0^T \langle \dot{h}_x, h_x \rangle dt = \frac{\gamma}{2} \underbrace{[\|h_x\|^2]_0^T}_{=0} = 0
1325: $$
1326: 
1327: For the third term, by strict convexity:
1328: 
1329: $$
1330: \int_0^T \langle (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)) h_x, h_x \rangle dt \geq \epsilon \int_0^T \|h_x\|^2 dt
1331: $$
1332: 
1333: **Step 4: Combine inequalities.**
1334: 
1335: Substituting into Step 2:
1336: 
1337: $$
1338: -\int_0^T \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt + 0 + \epsilon \int_0^T \|h_x\|^2 dt \leq 0
1339: $$
1340: 
1341: This gives:
1342: 
1343: $$
1344: \epsilon \int_0^T \|h_x\|^2 dt \leq \int_0^T \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt
1345: $$
1346: 
1347: **Step 5: Apply Poincaré inequality.**
1348: 
1349: For functions $h_x \in W^{1,2}_0([0,T], \mathbb{R}^d)$ (zero at boundaries), the Poincaré inequality states:
1350: 
1351: $$
1352: \int_0^T \|h_x\|^2 dt \leq C_P \int_0^T \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt
1353: $$
1354: 
1355: where $C_P = T^2/\pi^2$ is the Poincaré constant for the interval $[0,T]$.
1356: 
1357: **Step 6: Contradiction.**
1358: 
1359: From Step 4, if $\mathcal{L} h_x = 0$, then:
1360: 
1361: $$
1362: \epsilon \int \|h_x\|^2 dt \leq \int \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt
1363: $$
1364: 
1365: But the Poincaré inequality gives:
1366: 
1367: $$
1368: \int \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt \geq \frac{1}{C_P} \int \|h_x\|^2 dt = \frac{\pi^2}{T^2} \int \|h_x\|^2 dt
1369: $$
1370: 
1371: Combining:
1372: 
1373: $$
1374: \epsilon \int \|h_x\|^2 dt \leq \int \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt \quad \text{and} \quad \int \|\dot{h}_x\|^2 dt < \infty
1375: $$
1376: 
1377: For $\mathcal{L} h_x = 0$ to hold with $h_x(0) = h_x(T) = 0$, we need the only solution to be $h_x \equiv 0$. This is guaranteed when the operator $-\frac{d^2}{dt^2} - \gamma \frac{d}{dt} - \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}$ is **coercive** on $W^{2,2}_0$. Under strict convexity ($\epsilon > 0$) and positive damping ($\gamma > 0$), the operator is indeed coercive, forcing $h_x \equiv 0$, which contradicts $h_x \neq 0$.

hints.label: thm-degenerate-metric-nonconvex
hints.title: Degenerate Metric for Non-Convex Potentials
hints.content:
1383: :label: thm-degenerate-metric-nonconvex
1384: 
1385: If $U_{\text{eff}}$ is **non-convex**, the path space metric $g_{\mathcal{P}}$ is **positive semi-definite** (not strictly positive-definite), and can become **nearly degenerate** in the sense that the metric norm can be made arbitrarily small along certain perturbations.
1386: 
1387: Specifically, if there exists $x_0 \in \mathcal{X}$ and direction $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^d$ with $\xi^T \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_0) \xi < 0$, then for any $\epsilon > 0$, there exist non-zero perturbations $h_x \in W^{2,2}_0$ with $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) < \epsilon \|h_x\|_{W^{2,2}}^2$. Whether exact zero modes exist (metric degeneracy) depends on whether the linearized operator $\mathcal{L}$ admits non-trivial Dirichlet eigenfunctions on the finite interval $[0,T]$.
1388: 
1389: **Proof:**
1390: 
1391: By {prf:ref}`prop-metric-from-om-action`, the metric is:
1392: 
1393: $$
1394: g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \|\mathcal{L} h_x\|^2 dt \geq 0
1395: $$
1396: 
1397: where $\mathcal{L} h_x = \ddot{h}_x + \gamma \dot{h}_x + (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)) h_x$. Since this is an integral of a squared norm, it is **always non-negative**.
1398: 
1399: The metric has $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = 0$ if and only if:
1400: 
1401: $$
1402: \mathcal{L} h_x(t) = 0 \quad \text{for almost every } t \in [0,T]
1403: $$
1404: 
1405: **Existence of Zero Modes:** For non-convex potentials with $\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}$ having negative eigenvalues, the operator $\mathcal{L}$ can have non-trivial solutions to $\mathcal{L} h_x = 0$ with boundary conditions $h_x(0) = h_x(T) = 0$.
1406: 
1407: Consider a path passing through a saddle point $x_0$ where $\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_0)$ has a negative eigenvalue $\lambda < 0$ in direction $\xi$. The characteristic equation:
1408: 
1409: $$
1410: r^2 + \gamma r + \lambda = 0
1411: $$
1412: 
1413: has solutions:
1414: 
1415: $$
1416: r_{\pm} = \frac{-\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^2 + 4|\lambda|}}{2}
1417: $$
1418: 
1419: giving one positive and one negative real root: $r_+ > 0 > r_-$. A localized perturbation $h_x(t) = \phi(t) e^{r_+ t} \xi$ (where $\phi$ is a smooth cut-off function with $\phi(0) = \phi(T) = 0$) approximately satisfies $\mathcal{L} h_x \approx 0$ near the saddle point, representing an **unstable mode**.
1420: 
1421: By adjusting the cut-off to make boundary conditions exact, one can construct perturbations $h_x \neq 0$ with $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x)$ arbitrarily small (though strictly zero requires solving the boundary-value problem exactly, which may not always have solutions for finite $T$).

1381: 
1382: :::{prf:theorem} Degenerate Metric for Non-Convex Potentials
1383: :label: thm-degenerate-metric-nonconvex
1384: 
1385: If $U_{\text{eff}}$ is **non-convex**, the path space metric $g_{\mathcal{P}}$ is **positive semi-definite** (not strictly positive-definite), and can become **nearly degenerate** in the sense that the metric norm can be made arbitrarily small along certain perturbations.
1386: 
1387: Specifically, if there exists $x_0 \in \mathcal{X}$ and direction $\xi \in \mathbb{R}^d$ with $\xi^T \nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_0) \xi < 0$, then for any $\epsilon > 0$, there exist non-zero perturbations $h_x \in W^{2,2}_0$ with $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) < \epsilon \|h_x\|_{W^{2,2}}^2$. Whether exact zero modes exist (metric degeneracy) depends on whether the linearized operator $\mathcal{L}$ admits non-trivial Dirichlet eigenfunctions on the finite interval $[0,T]$.
1388: 
1389: **Proof:**
1390: 
1391: By {prf:ref}`prop-metric-from-om-action`, the metric is:
1392: 
1393: $$
1394: g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = \frac{1}{2\gamma T}\int_0^T \|\mathcal{L} h_x\|^2 dt \geq 0
1395: $$
1396: 
1397: where $\mathcal{L} h_x = \ddot{h}_x + \gamma \dot{h}_x + (\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_t)) h_x$. Since this is an integral of a squared norm, it is **always non-negative**.
1398: 
1399: The metric has $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = 0$ if and only if:
1400: 
1401: $$
1402: \mathcal{L} h_x(t) = 0 \quad \text{for almost every } t \in [0,T]
1403: $$
1404: 
1405: **Existence of Zero Modes:** For non-convex potentials with $\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}$ having negative eigenvalues, the operator $\mathcal{L}$ can have non-trivial solutions to $\mathcal{L} h_x = 0$ with boundary conditions $h_x(0) = h_x(T) = 0$.
1406: 
1407: Consider a path passing through a saddle point $x_0$ where $\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}(x_0)$ has a negative eigenvalue $\lambda < 0$ in direction $\xi$. The characteristic equation:
1408: 
1409: $$
1410: r^2 + \gamma r + \lambda = 0
1411: $$
1412: 
1413: has solutions:
1414: 
1415: $$
1416: r_{\pm} = \frac{-\gamma \pm \sqrt{\gamma^2 + 4|\lambda|}}{2}
1417: $$
1418: 
1419: giving one positive and one negative real root: $r_+ > 0 > r_-$. A localized perturbation $h_x(t) = \phi(t) e^{r_+ t} \xi$ (where $\phi$ is a smooth cut-off function with $\phi(0) = \phi(T) = 0$) approximately satisfies $\mathcal{L} h_x \approx 0$ near the saddle point, representing an **unstable mode**.
1420: 
1421: By adjusting the cut-off to make boundary conditions exact, one can construct perturbations $h_x \neq 0$ with $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x)$ arbitrarily small (though strictly zero requires solving the boundary-value problem exactly, which may not always have solutions for finite $T$).

hints.label: rem-metric-degeneracy
hints.title: Physical Interpretation of Degeneracy
hints.content:
1427: :label: rem-metric-degeneracy
1428: 
1429: The degeneracy (or near-degeneracy) of the path space metric for non-convex potentials has important physical consequences:
1430: 
1431: 1. **Multiple Transition Paths:** When $g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_x, h_x) = 0$ for $h_x \neq 0$, there exist infinitesimally close paths with the same action, indicating multiple local minima of the action functional.
1432: 
1433: 2. **Jacobi Fields:** Zero modes $h_x$ satisfying $\mathcal{L} h_x = 0$ are **Jacobi fields** indicating conjugate points where the path becomes unstable.
1434: 
1435: 3. **Rare Events:** Near saddle points, the metric degeneracy corresponds to the existence of multiple rare-event transition paths (instantons) with comparable probabilities.
1436: 
1437: 4. **Metastability:** The presence of zero modes signals metastable states separated by energy barriers, where the system can transition via different pathways.

hints.label: unlabeled-remark-309
hints.title: Non-Convex Potentials and Degenerate Geometry
hints.content:
1474: 
1475: :::{prf:remark} Non-Convex Potentials and Degenerate Geometry
1476: For general non-convex potentials (e.g., double-well, multiscale landscapes), neither strict convexity nor uniform lower bounds on $\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}}$ hold globally. In such cases:
1477: 
1478: **Degenerate Semi-Riemannian Structure:**
1479: 
1480: The path space metric is **positive semi-definite but nearly degenerate** (or exactly degenerate when zero modes exist). The metric remains non-negative everywhere, but can have arbitrarily small eigenvalues along unstable directions. Geodesics are still well-defined as critical points of the action, but they are **extremal paths** (stationary points) rather than necessarily **minimal paths**.
1481: 
1482: **Stability Interpretation:**
1483: 
1484: - Regions where $g_{\mathcal{P}} \succ 0$: Strictly positive-definite (stable path neighborhoods)
1485: - Regions where $g_{\mathcal{P}}$ has small eigenvalues: Nearly degenerate (multiple competing transition paths with similar action)
1486: 
1487: **Conjugate Points:**
1488: 
1489: The near-degeneracy of $g_{\mathcal{P}}$ signals the appearance of conjugate points (see {prf:ref}`thm-conjugate-points-saddles`), indicating path instability and multiplicity of transition mechanisms. Zero eigenvalues correspond to Jacobi fields along unstable directions.

hints.label: thm-geodesics-action-minimizing
hints.title: Geodesics as Action-Minimizing Paths
hints.content:
1513: :label: thm-geodesics-action-minimizing
1514: 
1515: In the path space $(\mathcal{P}, g_{\mathcal{P}})$ defined by the Onsager-Machlup action, geodesics connecting $\gamma_0, \gamma_1 \in \mathcal{P}$ are solutions to:
1516: 
1517: $$
1518: \min_{\Gamma: \gamma_0 \to \gamma_1} \int_0^1 \sqrt{g_{\mathcal{P}}[\Gamma(s)](\dot{\Gamma}(s), \dot{\Gamma}(s))} \, ds
1519: $$
1520: 
1521: These geodesics satisfy the geodesic equation:
1522: 
1523: $$
1524: \ddot{\Gamma}^i(s) + \Gamma_{jk}^i[\Gamma(s)] \dot{\Gamma}^j(s) \dot{\Gamma}^k(s) = 0
1525: $$
1526: 
1527: where $\Gamma_{jk}^i$ are the Christoffel symbols of $g_{\mathcal{P}}$.
1528: 
1529: **Physical Meaning:**
1530: 
1531: Geodesics represent the most probable **continuous family** of stochastic trajectories connecting two realizations. This is relevant for:

hints.label: def-path-space-curvature
hints.title: Riemann Curvature Tensor of Path Space
hints.content:
1539: :label: def-path-space-curvature
1540: 
1541: The **Riemann curvature tensor** of $(\mathcal{P}, g_{\mathcal{P}})$ is:
1542: 
1543: $$
1544: R_{\mathcal{P}}(h_1, h_2)h_3 := \nabla_{\mathcal{P},h_1} \nabla_{\mathcal{P},h_2} h_3 - \nabla_{\mathcal{P},h_2} \nabla_{\mathcal{P},h_1} h_3 - \nabla_{\mathcal{P},[h_1, h_2]} h_3
1545: $$
1546: 
1547: for $h_i \in H$ (tangent vectors).
1548: 
1549: **Sectional Curvature:**
1550: 
1551: $$
1552: K_{\mathcal{P}}(h_1, h_2) = \frac{g_{\mathcal{P}}(R_{\mathcal{P}}(h_1, h_2)h_2, h_1)}{g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_1, h_1) g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_2, h_2) - g_{\mathcal{P}}(h_1, h_2)^2}
1553: $$
1554: 
1555: **Scalar Curvature:**
1556: 
1557: $$
1558: R_{\mathcal{P}} = \sum_{i,j} K_{\mathcal{P}}(e_i, e_j)
1559: $$
hints.raw_directive:

hints.label: thm-path-curvature-fluctuations
hints.title: Path Space Curvature and Thermodynamic Fluctuations
hints.content:
1565: :label: thm-path-curvature-fluctuations
1566: 
1567: The sectional curvature $K_{\mathcal{P}}$ of path space encodes **correlations of thermodynamic fluctuations**:
1568: 
1569: $$
1570: K_{\mathcal{P}}(h_1, h_2) \propto \langle \delta Q[h_1] \delta Q[h_2] \rangle - \langle \delta Q[h_1] \rangle \langle \delta Q[h_2] \rangle
1571: $$
1572: 
1573: where $\delta Q[h]$ is the fluctuation in heat dissipation along perturbation $h$.
1574: 
1575: **Positive Curvature:**
1576: 
1577: $K_{\mathcal{P}} > 0$ indicates **anti-correlated fluctuations** (stabilizing).
1578: 
1579: **Negative Curvature:**
1580: 
1581: $K_{\mathcal{P}} < 0$ indicates **correlated fluctuations** (destabilizing, enhances rare events).
1582: 
1583: **Connection to Phase Transitions:**

hints.title: (Sketch)
hints.content:
1588: :::{prf:proof} (Sketch)
1589: 
1590: **Step 1:** The curvature arises from the third variation of the action:
1591: 
1592: $$
1593: R_{\mathcal{P}}(h_1, h_2) \sim D^3 S[\gamma](h_1, h_2, \cdot)
1594: $$
1595: 
1596: **Step 2:** Heat dissipation $Q[\gamma] = \int_0^T \gamma \|v_t\|^2 dt$ depends on the path. Its fluctuation is:
1597: 
1598: $$
1599: \delta Q[h] = \int_0^T 2\gamma \langle v_t, h_v(t) \rangle dt
1600: $$
1601: 
1602: **Step 3:** The covariance $\langle \delta Q[h_1] \delta Q[h_2] \rangle$ is computed via Wick's theorem for Gaussian path integrals, yielding an integral involving $\mathcal{G}^{-1}$ (inverse Hessian).
1603: 
1604: **Step 4:** By the Gauss-Codazzi equation, this covariance equals the curvature tensor contracted appropriately.

hints.label: def-jacobi-field
hints.title: Jacobi Field
hints.content:
1612: :label: def-jacobi-field
1613: 
1614: A **Jacobi field** along an extremal path $\gamma$ is a vector field $J(t) \in T_{\gamma(t)}\mathcal{M}$ satisfying the **Jacobi equation**:
1615: 
1616: $$
1617: \frac{D^2 J}{dt^2} + R_{\mathcal{M}}(\dot{\gamma}, J)\dot{\gamma} = 0
1618: $$
1619: 
1620: where $R_{\mathcal{M}}$ is the Riemann curvature tensor of the underlying manifold $\mathcal{M}$.
1621: 
1622: **Boundary Conditions:**
1623: 
1624: - $J(0) = 0$, $J(T) = 0$: Solutions indicate **conjugate points** (path instability)
1625: - $J(0) = 0$, $\dot{J}(0) = v_0$: Initial velocity $v_0$ determines the Jacobi field
1626: 
1627: **Physical Interpretation:**

hints.label: thm-conjugate-points-saddles
hints.title: Conjugate Points and Action Saddle Points
hints.content:
1633: :label: thm-conjugate-points-saddles
1634: 
1635: If a conjugate point exists at time $t^* \in (0, T]$ along the extremal path $\gamma$, then $\gamma$ is **not** a strict local minimum of the action. Instead, it is a saddle point.
1636: 
1637: **Consequence:**
1638: 
1639: For $T > t^*$, multiple local minima of the action exist, corresponding to different transition paths. This is the hallmark of **metastability** in stochastic dynamics.
1640: 
1641: **Application to Fragile Gas:**
1642: 
1643: Conjugate points appear when:
1644: 1. The potential $U(x)$ has negative curvature regions (saddle points)
1645: 2. The friction $\gamma$ is weak (underdamped limit)
1646: 3. The trajectory passes near a barrier
